docs.lead_paragraph: After insisting that he would leave the details to Congress, President Obama this month intensified his push to overhaul health care. Democrats, Republicans and special interests are battling to shape the legislation as it begins its journey through Congress. Three separate bills are in the pipeline. Leaders of the Senate Finance Committee hope to unveil a bipartisan measure in the near future. The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions began formal consideration of its plan this week. And Democrats from three House committees are writing a single plan that could be unveiled soon. In all the proposals, there is Democratic consensus on requiring that almost all Americans have insurance and on establishing an insurance marketplace. But lawmakers are struggling to resolve profound disagreements over whether to create a new government insurance plan, whether to impose new obligations on employers and how to generate the $1 trillion or so that the government will need over the next decade to help pay for universal coverage.
